sen.j: ジャポニズム（英語：Japonism）、あるいはジャポニスム（フランス語：Japonisme）とは、ヨーロッパで見られた日本趣味・日本心酔のこと。
sen.e: Japonism (Japonisme in French) means enjoying Japanese taste and adoring Japan, which spread in European countries.
Japonism (Japonisme in French) is a term for an interest in and an appreciation for Japanese arts that appeared in Europe.
Japonism (Japonisme in French) is a term for an interest in and an appreciation for Japanese arts that appeared in Europe.

sen.j: 本来「ジャポニスム」と呼ぶのが一般的だが、ここでは便宜上「ジャポニズム」に表記を統一する。
sen.e: Japonism is commonly pronounced 'Japonism', not 'Japonizm' in Japan, however this text uses 'Japonism' uniformly for convenience.
Japonism is commonly pronounced 'Japonism' as opposed to 'Japonisme,' and this is the term used throughout this article for convenience.
Japonism is commonly pronounced 'Japonism' as opposed to 'Japonisme,' and this is the term used throughout this article for convenience.

sen.j: ジャポニズムは単なる一時的な流行ではなく、当時の全ての先進国で30年以上も続いた運動である。
sen.e: Japonism is not a mere momentary trend, but a movement which continued for more than 30 years in every advanced country at that time.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Japonism was not a mere momentary trend but a movement which continued for over 30 years in developed countries at the time.
Japonism was not a mere momentary trend but a movement which continued for over 30 years in developed countries at the time.

sen.j: 欧米ではルネサンスに匹敵する、西洋近代的な美意識と科学的パースペクティヴの、大きな変革運動の一つの段階として見られている。
sen.e: In Western countries, it is seen as one stage of a big transformative movement in the Western modern sense of beauty and scientific perspective, which equals Renaissance.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: In Western countries, it is seen as one stage of a large transformative movement in the Western modern sense of beauty and scientific perspective, comparable to the Renaissance.
In Western countries, it is seen as one stage of a large transformative movement in the Western modern sense of beauty and scientific perspective, comparable to the Renaissance.

sen.j: 特に19世紀中頃の万国博覧会（国際博覧会）へ出品などをきっかけに、日本美術（浮世絵、琳派、工芸品など）が注目され、印象派やアール・ヌーヴォーの作家たちに影響を与えた。
sen.e: Particularly, displaying in exhibitions, such as an international exposition in the middle of the 19th century, shed light on Japan art (Ukiyoe (Japanese woodblock prints), works of Rinpa school, craftwork, etc.), which influenced artists of impressionist and Art Nouveau.

In particular, the exhibition of pieces at the world fairs (international expositions) of the mid-19th century, shed light on Japanese art (including ukiyoe woodblock prints, works of the Rinpa School and crafts), which influenced impressionist and Art Nouveau artists.

In particular, the exhibition of pieces at the world fairs (international expositions) of the mid-19th century, shed light on Japanese art (including ukiyoe woodblock prints, works of the Rinpa School and crafts), which influenced impressionist and Art Nouveau artists.

sen.j: ジャポニズムは画家を初めとして、作家・詩人たちにも大きな影響を与えた。
sen.e: Japonism significantly influenced not only painters but also writers and poets.
Japonism significantly influenced not only painters but also writers and poets.
Japonism significantly influenced not only painters but also writers and poets.

sen.j: たとえばフィンセント・ファン・ゴッホによる歌川広重の『名所江戸百景』の模写やクロード・モネの着物を着た少女が非常に有名である。
sen.e: For instance, a copy of Hiroshige UTAGAWA's "Meisho Edo Hyakkei" (100 selections of scenic views in Edo (old Tokyo)) by Vincent Van GOGH, as well as a work of a girl putting on a kimono painted by Claude Monet are quite famous.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Famous examples include Vincent Van Gogh's copy of Hiroshige UTAGAWA's "Meisho Edo Hyakkei" (100 selections of scenic views in Edo [old Tokyo]) and Claude Monet's painting of a girl wearing a kimono.
Famous examples include Vincent Van Gogh's copy of Hiroshige UTAGAWA's "Meisho Edo Hyakkei" (100 selections of scenic views in Edo [old Tokyo]) and Claude Monet's painting of a girl wearing a kimono.

sen.j: エドガー・ドガを初めとした画家の色彩感覚、人物や風景の構図にも影響を与えている。
sen.e: Furthermore, Japonism influenced the color sense, as well as the composition of figure paintings and landscape paintings, of painters like Edgar Degas.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Furthermore, Japonism influenced the perception of color as well as the composition of life and landscape paintings among painters such as Edgar Degas.
Furthermore, Japonism influenced the perception of color as well as the composition of life and landscape paintings among painters such as Edgar Degas.

sen.j: 和歌なども翻訳され、例えば扇子に記したマラルメの4行詩はその影響とされる。
sen.e: Waka (Japanese poetry) and others were also translated and influenced writers and poets such as Mallarme, which is proved in Mallarme's quatrain written down on a sensu (folding fan).
Waka (Japanese poetry) and others were also translated and influenced writers and poets such as Mallarme, as shown by Mallarme's quatrain written down on a sensu (folding fan).
Waka (Japanese poetry) and others were also translated and influenced writers and poets such as Mallarme, as shown by Mallarme's quatrain written down on a sensu (folding fan).

sen.j: ジャポニズムはオリエンタリズムから生じた結果ではあるが、たんなる一時的な流行に終わらなかった。
sen.e: Although Japonism was triggered by Orientalism, its popularity was not temporary.
Although Japonism was triggered by Orientalism, it was not merely a fleeting trend.
sen.cmt: "its popularity was not temporary" > "t was not merely a fleeting trend"
sen.e: Although Japonism was triggered by Orientalism, it was not merely a fleeting trend.

sen.j: 14世紀以降、西欧では何度か大きな文化的な変革が起きた。
sen.e: Large-scale cultural transformation had occurred in Western Europe since around the 14th century.
Repeated large-scale cultural transformations had occurred in Western Europe since around the 14th century.
Repeated large-scale cultural transformations had occurred in Western Europe since around the 14th century.

sen.j: 西洋近代を告げるルネサンスにおいては自然回帰運動が起き、芸術の世界では具象をありのままに捉えようとする近代的パースペクティヴが発展し、写実性を求める動きが次第に強まった。
sen.e: With the back-to-nature movement launched in Renaissance which announced the modernization of the Western culture, as well as with the modern perspective developed in the world of art which tried to catch figures as they were, a movement pursuing photorealistic was gradually intensified.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: A movement pursuing photorealism was gradually intensified with the back-to-nature movement launched during the Renaissance which brought the modernization of Western culture, as well as with the modern perspective developed in the world of art which attempted to depict figures as they were.

A movement pursuing photorealism was gradually intensified with the back-to-nature movement launched during the Renaissance which brought the modernization of Western culture, as well as with the modern perspective developed in the world of art which attempted to depict figures as they were.

sen.j: その結果、19世紀中頃にクールベらによって名実ともに写実主義が定着した。
sen.e: As a result, the realism was established both in name and in reality by COURBET and others in the middle of the 19th century.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: As a result, realism was established both in name and in reality by Courbet and others during the middle of the 19th century.
As a result, realism was established both in name and in reality by Courbet and others during the middle of the 19th century.

sen.j: 19世紀後半からは写実主義が衰え、印象主義を経て抽象画などのモダニズムに至る変革が起きた。
sen.e: After the decline of the realism in the latter half of the 19th century, a series of transformations produced the modernism, to which abstract paintings belonged, through the period of impressionism.
After the decline of realism in the latter half of the 19th century, there was a transformation to impressionism and then to modernism to which abstract paintings belonged.
After the decline of realism in the latter half of the 19th century, there was a transformation to impressionism and then to modernism to which abstract paintings belonged.

sen.j: この変革の最初の段階で決定的に作用を及ぼしたのがジャポニズムであったと考えられている。
sen.e: It is thought that Japonism decisively influenced these transformations in their early stage.
Japonism is thought to have decisively influenced these transformations at an early stage.
Japonism is thought to have decisively influenced these transformations at an early stage.

sen.j: ジャポニズムは単なる流行にとどまらず、それ以降1世紀近く続いた世界的な芸術運動の発端となったのである。
sen.e: Japonism was not only a trend but also a beginning of the worldwide art movement continued for about one century after that.
Japonism was not only a trend but also the beginning of a worldwide art movement that was to continue for nearly a century.
Japonism was not only a trend but also the beginning of a worldwide art movement that was to continue for nearly a century.

sen.j: 昨今では日本の漫画・アニメーションなどがフランスなどで高い人気を博しており、「現代のジャポニスム」といわれている。
sen.e: Japanese cartoon and animation, etc. gain high popularity in France and other countries today, which is called 'Modern Japonism.'
Japanese manga (comics) and animation have gained a high level of popularity in countries such as France, a phenomenon known as 'Modern Japonism.'
Japanese manga (comics) and animation have gained a high level of popularity in countries such as France, a phenomenon known as 'Modern Japonism.'

sen.j: なお、ルイ・ヴィトンのダミエキャンバスやモノグラム・キャンバスも当時のゴシック趣味、アールヌーヴォーの影響のほか、市松模様や家紋の影響もかかわっているとされる。
sen.e: A theory suggests that Damier Canvas and Monogram Canvas, traditional patterns of Louis VUITTON, were influenced not only by Gothic taste in those days and Art Nouveau but also by checkered pattern and family crest in Japan.

A theory suggests that Damier Canvas and Monogram Canvas patterns by Louis Vuitton were influenced not only by contemporary Gothic taste and Art Nouveau but also by Japanese checkered patterns and family crests.

A theory suggests that Damier Canvas and Monogram Canvas patterns by Louis Vuitton were influenced not only by contemporary Gothic taste and Art Nouveau but also by Japanese checkered patterns and family crests.

sen.j: ジャポネズリーの時代
sen.e: Period of Japonaiserie
Period of Japonaiserie
Period of Japonaiserie

sen.j: ジャポネズリーとは、異国趣味としての日本趣味のことである。
sen.e: Japonaiserie is enjoying Japan taste with regarding it as exoticism.
Japonaiserie is an interest in the exoticism of Japan.
Japonaiserie is an interest in the exoticism of Japan.

sen.j: オリエントや中国などの物産と同様に、当初は日本の工芸品も見た目の物珍しさで評価されていた。
sen.e: At first, craftwork of Japan was evaluated by its external curiosity, like products of Orient and China.
Japanese handicrafts were originally assessed according to their visual curiosity, like products of Orient and China.
Japanese handicrafts were originally assessed according to their visual curiosity, like products of Orient and China.

sen.j: ジャポネズリーはジャポニズムの一部、あるいは前段階として解釈されている。
sen.e: Japonaiserie is understood as part of Japonism or the former stage of Japonism.
Japonaiserie is understood to be part of Japonism or the former stage of Japonism.
Japonaiserie is understood to be part of Japonism or the former stage of Japonism.

sen.j: 嘉永年間、黒船来航により開国した日本に、西洋からの商船が押し寄せた。
sen.e: During 1848-1854, merchant ships from the Western countries rushed for Japan that had marked the end of a long period of isolation after the arrival of the Black Ships.
Between 1848 and 1854, many merchant ships from Western countries sailed to Japan which had recently reopened to trade due to the arrival of foreign Black Ships.
Between 1848 and 1854, many merchant ships from Western countries sailed to Japan which had recently reopened to trade due to the arrival of foreign Black Ships.

sen.j: 当時発達しつつあった写真技術と印刷技術により、日本の様子が西洋に広く知られるようになった。
sen.e: Circumstances of Japan were widely introduced to the Western countries due to the photographic technology and the printing technique that had been developing at that time.
Conditions in Japan became widely known in Western countries as a result of the photographic and printing technology that was being developed at that time.
Conditions in Japan became widely known in Western countries as a result of the photographic and printing technology that was being developed at that time.

sen.j: 他の美術工芸品とともに浮世絵という版画がヨーロッパとアメリカでまたたく間に人気を博するようになった。
sen.e: Japanese woodblock prints called Ukiyoe, as well as other arts and crafts objects, became popular among European countries and the United States immediately.
Japanese woodblock prints called ukiyoe as well as other arts and crafts instantly became popular in Europe and the United States.
Japanese woodblock prints called ukiyoe as well as other arts and crafts instantly became popular in Europe and the United States.

sen.j: ジャポニズムの第一段階は日本の美術品、特に浮世絵版画の熱狂的な収集から始まる。
sen.e: The first stage of Japonism started from enthusiastically collecting the Japanese works of art, especially Ukiyoe woodblock prints.
The first stage of Japonism started from the enthusiastic collection of Japanese works of art, particularly ukiyoe woodblock prints.
The first stage of Japonism started from the enthusiastic collection of Japanese works of art, particularly ukiyoe woodblock prints.

sen.j: その最初の例はフランスのパリであった。
sen.e: The first example was in Paris, France.
The first example of this was in Paris, France.
The first example of this was in Paris, France.

sen.j: 1856年頃、フランスのエッチング画家フェリックス・ブラックモンが、摺師の仕事場で『北斎漫画』を目にした。
sen.e: A French etcher Felix BRACQUEMOND chanced on "Hokusai Manga" (cartoon produced by Hokusai KATSUSHIKA) at the workshop of a surishi (a printer) in around 1856.
The French etcher Félix Bracquemond chanced upon "Hokusai Manga" (Hokusai's Sketches) at a printer's workshop around 1856.
The French etcher Félix Bracquemond chanced upon "Hokusai Manga" (Hokusai's Sketches) at a printer's workshop around 1856.

sen.j: それらは磁器の輸送の際に詰め物に使われていたものだったという。
sen.e: It seems that Hokusai Manga was printed on the packing material for shipping porcelain.
It seems that Hokusai Manga was printed on the packing material for shipping porcelain.
It is said that Hokusai Manga was used as the packing material for shipping porcelain.

sen.j: 1860年から1861年にかけて出版された日本についての本の中では、浮世絵がモノクロで紹介されている。
sen.e: Ukiyoe is introduced in monochrome in the book on Japan published from 1860 to 1861.
Ukiyoe is introduced in monochrome in a book on Japan published from 1860 to 1861.
Ukiyoe is introduced in monochrome in a book on Japan published from 1860 to 1861.

sen.j: シャルル・ボードレールは、1861年に手紙を書いている。
sen.e: Charles BAUDELAIRE wrote a letter in 1861.
Charles Baudelaire wrote a letter in 1861
Charles Baudelaire wrote a letter in 1861

sen.j: 「かなり前になりますが、私は1箱の日本の工芸品を受け取り、それらを友人たちと分け合いました……」。
sen.e: "I received a box filled with Japanese craftwork long ago. I shared them with my friends."
"Long ago I received a box filled with Japanese crafts which I shared among my friends."
sen.cmt: Reformed original single sentence.Rewritten to read professionally.
sen.e: Long ago I received a box filled with Japanese crafts which I shared among my friends.'

sen.j: その翌年にはラ・ポルト・シノワーズ（「中国の門」、La Porte Chinoise）という浮世絵を含むいろいろな日本製品を売る店がリヴォリ通りというパリで最もおしゃれな商店街に開店した。
sen.e: In the next year, a store named La Porte Chinoise, at which various Japanese products including Ukiyoe were sold, was opened in Rivoli street, most fashionable shopping street in Paris.
In the next year, a shop named La Porte Chinoise, at which various Japanese products including ukiyoe were sold, opened on Rue de Rivoli, the most fashionable shopping street in Paris.
In the next year, a shop named La Porte Chinoise, at which various Japanese products including ukiyoe were sold, opened on Rue de Rivoli, the most fashionable shopping street in Paris.

sen.j: 1871年には、カミーユ・サン＝サーンスが作曲し、ルイ・ガレが台本を書いたオペラ『ラ・プランセス・ジョーヌ』（『黄色人の王女』、La Princesse jaune）が公開された。
sen.e: In 1871, an opera "La Princesse jaune," whose music was composed by Camille Saint-Saens and scenario was written by Louis GALLAIT, was opened to the public.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: In 1871, the opera "La princesse jaune" (The Yellow Princess)" composed by Camille Saint-Saëns and written by Louis Gallet opened to the public.
sen.cmt: Rewritten to read professionally and use correct names.
sen.e: In 1871, the opera "La princesse jaune" (The Yellow Princess)" composed by Camille Saint-Saëns and written by Louis Gallet opened to the public.

sen.j: その物語はオランダ人の少女が芸術家のボーイフレンドが熱中している浮世絵に嫉妬するというものだった。
sen.e: The motif of the opera was a jealousy in a Dutch girl over Ukiyoe, to which her boyfriend devoted himself.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: The story revolves around the jealousy that a Dutch girl feels for an ukiyoe with which her boyfriend has become infatuated.
The story revolves around the jealousy that a Dutch girl feels for an ukiyoe with which her boyfriend has become infatuated.

sen.j: ブラックモンによる浮世絵の古典的名作の最初の発見にもかかわらず、当初ヨーロッパに輸入された大半の浮世絵は、同時代である1860～1870年代の絵師によるものだった。
sen.e: The Ukiyoe first discovered by BRACQUEMOND was a classic masterpiece produced by Hokusai KATSUSHIKA, however, most Ukiyoe exported to Europe at first were the works of painters in the 1860s and 1870s, contemporaries of Hokusai KATSUSHIKA.
sen.cmt: ヨーロッパに輸入，は日本側の記載で考えると不自然なので輸出としました。
sen.e: The Ukiyoe first discovered by Bracquemond was a classical masterpiece by Hokusai KATSUSHIKA, but most ukiyoe initially exported to Europe were the relatively modern work of painters of the 1860s and 1870s.

The Ukiyoe first discovered by Bracquemond was a classical masterpiece by Hokusai KATSUSHIKA, but most ukiyoe initially exported to Europe were the relatively modern work of painters of the 1860s and 1870s.

sen.j: それ以前の巨匠たちが紹介され、評価されるのはもう少しあとのことになる。
sen.e: It was a little later when masters, who had produced masterpieces prior to those painters, were introduced to the European countries and appreciated.
It was a little later when masters who had produced works prior to those painters were introduced to Europe and became appreciated.
It was a little later when masters who had produced works prior to those painters were introduced to Europe and became appreciated.

sen.j: また、同時期のアメリカのインテリたちは、江戸の版画などは低俗で一時の流行に過ぎない。
sen.e: Moreover, intellectuals in the United States existed in that period insisted that such works as woodblock prints in Edo were vulgar and a temporal trend.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Intellectuals in the United States at the time asserted that Edo period works such as woodblock prints were vulgar and nothing more than a passing trend.
Intellectuals in the United States at the time asserted that Edo period works such as woodblock prints were vulgar and nothing more than a passing trend.

sen.j: 雪舟や周文などのような日本の洗練された宗教的、国家的遺産とは区別されるべきものだと主張した。
sen.e: They added such works should be distinguished from Japanese sophisticated religious heritage and national heritage produced by Sesshu, Shubun, etc.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: They added such pieces should be distinguished from sophisticated works of Japanese religious and national heritage produced by artists such as Sesshu and Shubun.
They added such pieces should be distinguished from sophisticated works of Japanese religious and national heritage produced by artists such as Sesshu and Shubun.

sen.j: 1870年代と1880年代、多くのフランスのコレクターや作家、芸術評論家が日本に渡った。
sen.e: A large number of collectors, writers, and art critics in France went to Japan in the 1870s and 1880s.
A large number of collectors, writers, and art critics from France went to Japan during the 1870s and 1880s.
A large number of collectors, writers, and art critics from France went to Japan during the 1870s and 1880s.

sen.j: その結果、ヨーロッパ、特にフランスにおいて日本の美学に関する出版物と工芸品がさらに広く知られるようになった。
sen.e: As a result, publications and craftwork concerning the aesthetics of Japan were spread more in Europe, especially in France.
As a result, publications and crafts related to the aesthetics of Japan became more widely known in Europe, particularly in France.
As a result, publications and crafts related to the aesthetics of Japan became more widely known in Europe, particularly in France.

sen.j: 中でも、自由主義経済学者アンリ・チェルヌースキ、批評家テオドール・デュレ、数年間江戸に住んで医学を教授した英国のコレクターのウィリアム・アンダーソンがその代表者である。
sen.e: Above all, a liberal economist Henri CERNUSCHI, a critic Theodore DURET and a British collector William Anderson who lived in Edo for several years to teach medicine were famous.
Notable examples include the liberal economist Henri Cernuschi, the critic Théodore Duret and a British collector William Anderson who lived in Edo for several years to teach medicine.
sen.cmt: Rewritten to read professionally and correct names.
sen.e: Notable examples include the liberal economist Henri Cernuschi, the critic Théodore Duret and a British collector William Anderson who lived in Edo for several years to teach medicine.

sen.j: 現在でも、アンダーソンのコレクションは大英博物館で見ることができる。
sen.e: Even now, Anderson's collection is opened to the public at British Museum.
Even now, Anderson's collection is on public display at the British Museum.
Even now, Anderson's collection is on public display at the British Museum.

sen.j: ジャポニズムの広がりに伴って、林忠正のような日本人美術商もパリで開業し始めた。
sen.e: Taking advantage of the spread of Japonism, Japanese art dealer like Tadamasa HAYASHI started a business in Paris.
Taking advantage of the spread of Japonism, Japanese art dealers like Tadamasa HAYASHI started to do business in Paris.
Taking advantage of the spread of Japonism, Japanese art dealers like Tadamasa HAYASHI started to do business in Paris.

sen.j: 1878年のパリ万博では、数多くの日本の工芸品が展示され人気を博した。
sen.e: In the Paris Universal Exposition in 1878, a lot of Japanese craftwork were exhibited and enjoyed great popularity.
A lot of Japanese crafts were exhibited at the 1879 Paris Universal Exposition and enjoyed great popularity.
A lot of Japanese crafts were exhibited at the 1879 Paris Universal Exposition and enjoyed great popularity.

tit.j: ジャポネズリーからジャポニズムへ

sen.j: 右のマネの絵はジャポネズリーの代表的なものであると考えられる。
sen.e: The picture by MANET shown in the right is thought to be typical of Japonaiserie.
The picture by Manet shown in the right is thought to be typical of Japonaiserie.
The picture by Manet shown in the right is thought to be typical of Japonaiserie.

sen.j: 人物の後ろに浮世絵などの日本の絵画がちりばめられている。
sen.e: In the background of portrait, several pieces of Japanese pictures like Ukiyoe were drawn.
The background of the portrait includes Japanese pictures such as ukiyoe.
The background of the portrait includes Japanese pictures such as ukiyoe.

sen.j: この作品そのものには日本の絵画の表現方法が顕著に取込まれているわけではないが、マネ自身の日本趣味を表している。
sen.e: Although the expressive method used in Japanese pictures was not directly adopted in this picture, this picture shows that MANET loved the Japanese taste.
Although the expressive method of Japanese pictures is not obviously incorporated into this painting, it shows Manet's interest in Japan.
Although the expressive method of Japanese pictures is not obviously incorporated into this painting, it shows Manet's interest in Japan.

sen.j: この項の冒頭にあるフィンセント・ファン・ゴッホの絵も同様の感覚によるものであるとも考えられる。
sen.e: The picture by Vincent Van GOGH at the beginning of this text may show the similar inclination in GOGH.
It is thought that the painting at the beginning of this text reveals similar inclinations in Vincent Van Gogh.
It is thought that the painting at the beginning of this text reveals similar inclinations in Vincent Van Gogh.

sen.j: このように日本の芸術の評価は異国趣味の一つに過ぎなかった。
sen.e: Thus, the arts of Japan were only evaluated as one of the exoticisms at first.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Thus Japanese art was only evaluated as an aspect of exoticism.
Thus Japanese art was only evaluated as an aspect of exoticism.

sen.j: しかし浮世絵などで使われていた日本独特の空間表現や色彩感覚が、次第にヨーロッパの芸術家に取り入れられ「～イスム」となっていく。
sen.e: However, the spatial expression and sense of color peculiar to the Japan art, which were used in Ukiyoe and others, were gradually adopted by artists in Europe, with the result that 'Japonaiserie' grew into 'Japonism.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: However, the spatial expression and sense of color peculiar to Japan art, which were used in ukiyoe and other works, were gradually adopted by artists in Europe, resulting in 'Japonaiserie' developing into 'Japonism.'
sen.cmt: Slightly reworded to read more naturally.
sen.e: However, the spatial expression and sense of color peculiar to Japan art, which were used in ukiyoe and other works, were gradually adopted by artists in Europe, resulting in 'Japonaiserie' developing into 'Japonism.'

sen.j: 葛飾北斎や喜多川歌麿を含む日本の画家の作品は絶大な影響をヨーロッパに与えた。
sen.e: Works of Japanese painters including Hokusai KATSUSHIKA and Utamaro KITAGAWA exerted a dramatic influence on artists in Europe.
Works by Japanese painters including Hokusai KATSUSHIKA and Utamaro KITAGAWA exerted a dramatic influence on artists in Europe.
Works by Japanese painters including Hokusai KATSUSHIKA and Utamaro KITAGAWA exerted a dramatic influence on artists in Europe.

sen.j: 日本では文明開化が起こり、浮世絵などの出版物が急速に衰えていく一方で、日本美術はヨーロッパで絶大な評価を受けていた。
sen.e: While publication including Ukiyoe rapidly declined due to civilization and enlightenment in Japan, Japan art was highly evaluated in Europe.
While publications including traditional Japanese art such as ukiyoe rapidly declined in Japan due to Westernization, Japanese art was highly praised in Europe.
sen.cmt: Retranslated to better reflect source text.
sen.e: While publications including traditional Japanese art such as ukiyoe rapidly declined in Japan due to Westernization, Japanese art was highly praised in Europe.

sen.j: 日本美術から影響を受けたアーティストにはピエール・ボナール、エドゥアール・マネ、アンリ・ド・トゥールーズ＝ロートレック、メアリー・カサット、エドガー・ドガ、ピエール＝オーギュスト・ルノワール、ジェームズ・マクニール・ホイッスラー、クロード・モネ、フィンセント・ファン・ゴッホ、カミーユ・ピサロ、ポール・ゴーギャン、グスタフ・クリムトなど数え上げたらきりがない。
sen.e: There are a large number of artists in Europe who were influenced by Japan art, such as Pierre BONNARD, Edouard MANET, Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, Mary CASSATT, Edgar DEGAS, Pierre-Auguste RENOIR, James McNeill WHISTLER, Claude MONET, Vincent Van GOGH, Camille PISSARRO, Paul GAUGUIN and Gustav KLIMT.

There are a large number of artists who were influenced by Japanese art including Pierre Bonnard, Édouard Manet, Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, Mary Cassatt, Edgar Degas, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, James McNeill Whistler, Claude Monet, Vincent Van Gogh, Camille Pissarro, Paul Gauguin and Gustav Klimt.
sen.cmt: Rewritten to better reflect source text, read more professionally and correct names.
sen.e: There are a large number of artists who were influenced by Japanese art including Pierre Bonnard, Édouard Manet, Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, Mary Cassatt, Edgar Degas, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, James McNeill Whistler, Claude Monet, Vincent Van Gogh, Camille Pissarro, Paul Gauguin and Gustav Klimt.

sen.j: ありとあらゆる分野が日本の影響を受けたが、版画の技術だけは驚くほど影響を受けなかった。
sen.e: Every field was affected by Japan, however, only the technology of woodblock print was unaffected surprisingly.
Every artistic field was influenced by Japan with the surprising exception of printing which remained unaffected.
Every artistic field was influenced by Japan with the surprising exception of printing which remained unaffected.

sen.j: それは、ヨーロッパで主流だったのはリトグラフであって、木版画ではなかったからである。
sen.e: The reason is that the mainstream of the printing technology in Europe was lithograph, not woodblock print.
This is because mainstream printing in Europe was lithography as opposed to woodblock printing.
This is because mainstream printing in Europe was lithography as opposed to woodblock printing.

sen.j: 日本の影響を抜きにして、アンリ・ド・トゥールーズ＝ロートレックのリトグラフやポスターについて語ることなど考えられない。
sen.e: However, no one can talk about lithograph and poster produced by Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec without taking account of the influence exerted by Japan art.
However, it is not possible to discuss the lithography and posters of Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec without taking considering of the influence exerted by Japanese art.
However, it is not possible to discuss the lithography and posters of Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec without taking considering of the influence exerted by Japanese art.

sen.j: 木版画によるジャポニズムの作品が作られるようになるのは、モノクロではあったものの、ポール・ゴーギャンとフェリックス・ヴァロットンが最初となる。
sen.e: Paul GAUGUIN and Felix VALLOTTON were the first artists to produce the works adopting Japonism (Japanese taste) in woodblock print, although they were printed in monochrome.
Paul Gauguin and Félix Vallotton were the first artists to produce work incorporating Japonism into woodblock printing, although these were printed in monochrome.
sen.cmt: Rewritten to read professionally and correct names.
sen.e: Paul Gauguin and Félix Vallotton were the first artists to produce work incorporating Japonism into woodblock printing, although these were printed in monochrome.

sen.j: イギリスへの日本美術の伝達にはジェームズ・マクニール・ホイッスラーが重要な役割を果たした。
sen.e: James McNeill WHISTLER played an important role in the transmission of Japanese arts to Britain.
James McNeill Whistler played an important role in the transmission of Japanese art to Britain.
James McNeill Whistler played an important role in the transmission of Japanese art to Britain.

sen.j: 当時パリは日本の物産の集散地として知られており、ホイッスラーは滞在中に優れたコレクションを蓄積した。
sen.e: Since Paris was known as a distribution or trading center of Japanese products at that time, WHISTLER made an excellent collection of Japan art during his stay in Paris.
Since Paris was known as a distribution or trading center of Japanese products at that time, Whistler amassed an excellent collection of Japan art during his stay in Paris.
Since Paris was known as a distribution or trading center of Japanese products at that time, Whistler amassed an excellent collection of Japan art during his stay in Paris.

sen.j: フィンセント・ファン・ゴッホのいくつかの作品は浮世絵のスタイルを模倣したり、それ自体をモチーフにしたりしている。
sen.e: Some works by Vincent Van GOGH imitated the style of Ukiyoe, or used Ukiyoe as motifs.
Some works by Vincent Van Gogh imitated the style of ukiyoe or used ukiyoe as motifs.
Some works by Vincent Van Gogh imitated the style of ukiyoe or used ukiyoe as motifs.

sen.j: たとえばタンギー爺さん（あるアートショップのオーナー）の肖像画には、背景に6つの浮世絵が描かれている。
sen.e: For instance, six pieces of Ukiyoe are drawn in the background of the work titled "Portrait of Pere Tanguy" (owner of an art shop).
For instance, six ukiyoe pieces are included in the background of the work titled "Portrait of Pere Tanguy" (owner of an art shop).
For instance, six ukiyoe pieces are included in the background of the work titled "Portrait of Pere Tanguy" (owner of an art shop).

sen.j: また彼は、1886年、渓斎英泉の浮世絵をパリの雑誌『パリ・イリュストレ』（Paris Illustré）で見つけた後、1887年に《娼婦》を描いている。
sen.e: Moreover, after he chanced on a piece of Ukiyoe produced by Eisen KEISAI in "Paris Illustre," a magazine published in Paris, he painted a picture titles 《The prostitute 》 in 1886.
Moreover, after he chanced on a piece of Ukiyoe by Eisen KEISAI in "Paris Illustre," a magazine published in Paris, he painted a picture entitled 'The Prostitute' in 1886.
Moreover, in 1886, after he chanced on a piece of Ukiyoe by Eisen KEISAI in "Paris Illustre," a magazine published in Paris, he painted a picture entitled 'The Prostitute' in 1887.

sen.j: ゴッホはこの時すでにアントウェルペンで浮世絵版画を収集していた。
sen.e: GOGH had already collected Japanese woodblock prints in Antwerp.
GOGH had already collected Japanese woodblock prints in Antwerp.
Gogh had already collected Japanese woodblock prints in Antwerp.

sen.j: 音楽に関しては、ジャコモ・プッチーニの有名な『蝶々夫人』がジャポニズムの影響を受けている。
sen.e: In the field of music, the opera "Madama Butterfly" composed by Giacomo PUCCINI was influenced by Japonism.
In the field of music, the opera 'Madama Butterfly' composed by Giacomo Puccini was influenced by Japonism.
In the field of music, the opera "Madama Butterfly" composed by Giacomo Puccini was influenced by Japonism.

sen.j: また、ウィリアム・ギルバート (劇作家)とアーサー・サリヴァンによる有名なオペレッタ『ミカド (オペレッタ)』は、ロンドンのナイツブリッジで行われた日本の展示会から着想を得たものである。
sen.e: Moreover, the famous operetta "The Mikado" by a playwright William GILLBERT and a composer Arthur SULLIVAN took a hint from the exhibition of Japan art held at Knightsbridge in London.
Moreover, the famous operetta 'The Mikado' by playwright William Gilbert and a composer Arthur Sullivan was inspired by an exhibition of Japanese art held at Knightsbridge in London.
Moreover, the famous operetta "The Mikado" by playwright William Gilbert and a composer Arthur Sullivan was inspired by an exhibition of Japanese art held at Knightsbridge in London.

sen.j: これらのアーティストは、多くの日本美術の特徴を取り入れた。
sen.e: These artists adopted various features of Japan art.
These artists adopted many features of Japanese art.
These artists adopted many features of Japanese art.

sen.j: ジャポニズムの流行った当時、欧米のアーティストは日本美術の不規則性と非対称性に大変関心を寄せた。
sen.e: At that time when Japonism enjoyed popularity, artists in the Western countries had great interest in irregularity and asymmetry property of Japan art.
At that time when Japonism enjoyed popularity, artists in Western countries had a great interest in the irregularity and asymmetry of Japan art.
At that time when Japonism enjoyed popularity, artists in Western countries had a great interest in the irregularity and asymmetry of Japan art.

sen.j: 西洋のものとは異なる遠近法が用いられており、中心が中央から外れて構成されている。
sen.e: Japan art adopts its own perspective difference from the West art, putting the center of the work apart from the middle.
Japanese art uses perspective differently from Western art, placing the focus away from the centre.
Japanese art uses perspective differently from Western art, placing the focus away from the centre.

sen.j: また写実的陰影法も無く、鮮やかな色彩で平面構成がなされている。
sen.e: In addition, without using the realistic shading method, Japan art creates a two-dimensional space with bright colors.
In addition, it utilizes bright colors and a planar construction without the use of realistic shading.
In addition, it utilizes bright colors and a planar construction without the use of realistic shading.

sen.j: これらの要素は19世紀までの画家にとって前提であったローマン・グレコ様式（Roman-Greco art）の正反対、まさに対極にあるものであった。
sen.e: These elements were utterly different from the Roman-Greco art which was the foundation for painters until the 19th century.
These elements were completely different from the Roman-Greco art which was the foundation for painters until the 19th century.
These elements were completely different from the Roman-Greco art which was the foundation for painters until the 19th century.

sen.j: 西洋の画家たちが近代的な表現技法に行き詰まりを感じているなか、日本のアートは彼らの心理を、伝統に束縛された慣習から解き放ったひとつの契機となったのである。
sen.e: In such a period when painters in the West reached a deadlock in a modern expression technique, an encounter with Japanese arts became an opportunity to free their mentalities from the custom restrained by tradition.

In a period when painters in the West reached a deadlock in modern expression techniques, an encounter with Japanese art became an opportunity to free their minds from the customs restrained by tradition.

In a period when painters in the West reached a deadlock in modern expression techniques, an encounter with Japanese art became an opportunity to free their minds from the customs restrained by tradition.

sen.j: 浮世絵は線で構成されており、何も無い空間と図柄のある部分にくっきりと分かれ、立体感がほとんど無い。
sen.e: Ukiyoe is drawn by line, having two clearly separated spaces, space with nothing and space with designs, which shows little stereoscopic effect.
Ukiyoe are comprised of lines, clearly separated into empty space and patterns, which gives little stereoscopic effect.
Ukiyoe are comprised of lines, clearly separated into empty space and patterns, which gives little stereoscopic effect.

sen.j: これらの特徴はアール・ヌーボーに影響を与えた。
sen.e: These features influenced Art Nouveau.
These features influenced Art Nouveau.
These features influenced Art Nouveau.

sen.j: 浮世絵の直線と曲線による表現方法は、その後、世界中の全ての分野の絵画、グラフィックで当たり前のように見ることができるようになった。
sen.e: The expression technique using straight line and curved line, which is peculiar to Ukiyoe, became a commonly used technique in every field of paintings and graphic arts afterwards.
The ukiyoe technique of using straight and curved lines subsequently became commonly used in every field of painting and graphic design.
The ukiyoe technique of using straight and curved lines subsequently became commonly used in every field of painting and graphic design.

sen.j: これらの浮世絵から取り入れられた形状と色彩構成は、現代アートにおける抽象表現の成立要素のひとつと考えられる。
sen.e: The form and color component adopted from these Ukiyoe are thought to be an element of the abstract expression in the modern art.
The form and color composition adopted from these ukiyoe are thought to be an element of expression in modern art.
The form and color composition adopted from these ukiyoe are thought to be an element of expression in modern art.

sen.j: ジャポニズムによって、その後の家具や衣料から宝石に到るまであらゆる工芸品のグラフィックデザインに、日本的な要素が取り入れられるようになった。
sen.e: Due to Japonism, Japanese-tasted elements were adopted to the later graphic design of all craftwork, from furniture and clothes to jewels.
As a result of Japonism, Japanese elements came to be incorporated into the later graphic design of all crafts ranging from furniture and clothing to jewelry.
As a result of Japonism, Japanese elements came to be incorporated into the later graphic design of all crafts ranging from furniture and clothing to jewelry.

sen.j: 左上の絵は19世紀中頃の写実主義のフランスの画家、アンリ・ファンタン＝ラトゥールの『テーブルの隅』という絵である。
sen.e: The picture shown at the upper left is a picture titled "Corner of the table" painted by Henri Fantin-Latour, a French realism painter in the middle of the 19th century.
The picture shown in the upper left is entitled "Corner of the table" and was painted by Henri Fantin-Latour, a French realism painter of the mid-19th century.
The picture shown in the upper left is entitled "Corner of the table" and was painted by Henri Fantin-Latour, a French realism painter of the mid-19th century.

sen.j: 左下は世紀末のフランス画家、アンリ・ド・トゥールーズ＝ロートレックのポスター画である。
sen.e: The picture at the lower left is a poster paint by Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, a French painter in the end of the 19th century.
The picture in the lower left is a poster by Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, a French painter of the late 19th century.
The picture in the lower left is a poster by Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, a French painter of the late 19th century.

sen.j: ロートレックはジャポニズムの影響を強く受けた画家の一人である。
sen.e: Lautrec was a painter who was strongly influenced by Japonism.
Lautrec was a painter who was strongly influenced by Japonism.
Lautrec was a painter who was strongly influenced by Japonism.

sen.j: このロートレックのポスターは現代人の目には特別なものには映らないが、
sen.e: This Lautrec's poster may not appear as an especial work in the eyes of today's people.
This poster by Lautrec may not appear to be special in the eyes of modern people.
This poster by Lautrec may not appear to be special in the eyes of modern people.

sen.j: 当時の西洋人にとってはかなり斬新な表現方法を使った絵であった。
sen.e: However, Lautrec used such an expression technique that the Westerner in those days might have felt quite curious.
However, it uses a technique that would have been novel to Westerners of the time.
However, it uses a technique that would have been novel to Westerners of the time.

sen.j: まず、ロートレックの絵にはテーブルのラインが画面を真っ二つに切るように斜めに入っている。
sen.e: First of all, the edge line of the table in this Lautrec's poster is running obliquely as if it cuts the picture into two exact halves.
First of all, the edge line of the table in this poster runs diagonally as if cutting the picture exactly in half.
First of all, the edge line of the table in this poster runs diagonally as if cutting the picture exactly in half.

sen.j: ジャポニズム以前の絵画では、このように大胆に斜めのラインが入ることは珍しい。
sen.e: In the paintings before the introduction of Japonism, such a bold oblique line was hardly observed.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Such bold diagonal lines were rarely seen in paintings prior to Japonism.
Such bold diagonal lines were rarely seen in paintings prior to Japonism.

sen.j: ファンタン＝ラトゥールの絵のように水平に入るのが普通であった。
sen.e: Line drawn horizontally was usual as shown in the picture painted by Fantin-Latour.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Horizontal lines were the norm as shown in the picture painted by Fantin-Latour.
sen.cmt: "Line drawn horizontally was usual" > "Horizontal lines were the norm"
sen.e: Horizontal lines were the norm as shown in the picture painted by Fantin-Latour.

sen.j: これは右の広重の浮世絵に見られるような構図がインスピレーションになっていると考えられている。
sen.e: It is thought that the composition of Ukiyoe produced by Hiroshige, shown in the right, provided Lautrec with an inspiration.
It is thought that the composition of ukiyoe produced by Hiroshige, shown in the right, provided Lautrec with inspiration.
It is thought that the composition of ukiyoe produced by Hiroshige, shown in the right, provided Lautrec with inspiration.

sen.j: また、ファンタン＝ラトゥールの絵では遠近法と陰影、細部の描写により立体感を表現している。
sen.e: Moreover, Fantin-Latour represented the solidity by using perspective and shading as well as depicting details
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Moreover, Fantin-Latour created a feeling of solidity by using perspective and shading as well as the depiction of detail.
sen.cmt: "represented the solidity" > "created a feeling of solidity""depicting details" > "the depiction of detail"Added full-stop
sen.e: Moreover, Fantin-Latour created a feeling of solidity by using perspective and shading as well as the depiction of detail.

sen.j: ロートレックの方は平面の組み合わせで描写され、立体感の表現は全く放棄されている。
sen.e: Meanwhile, Lautrec completely neglected the solidity, using the technique of combining various planes.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Meanwhile, Lautrec completely abandoned three-dimensionality, using the technique of combining various planes.
Meanwhile, Lautrec completely abandoned three-dimensionality, using the technique of combining various planes.

sen.j: 人物や物体の輪郭が線で表現されるのも、ジャポニズム以前のヨーロッパではあまり見られない表現方法であった。
sen.e: The technique in which the outline of person or objects is drawn in line was rarely observed in Europe before the introduction of Japonism.
The technique in which people or objects are outlined was rarely seen in Europe before the introduction of Japonism.
The technique in which people or objects are outlined was rarely seen in Europe before the introduction of Japonism.

sen.j: 色使いも大胆で鮮明な原色が画面のかなりの面積を占めている。
sen.e: Coloring is so bold that bright garish colors occupy a considerable area of the picture.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: The use of color is bold, and vivid primary colors occupy a considerable area of the picture.
sen.cmt: "Coloring is so bold that bright garish colors" > "The use of color is bold, and vivid primary colors"
sen.e: The use of color is bold, and vivid primary colors occupy a considerable area of the picture.

sen.j: 油彩とリトグラフという比較障害があるとしても、ファンタン＝ラトゥールの絵とは好対照である。
sen.e: This is quite contrary to the coloring in the picture painted by Fantin-Latour, even if there are some impossibility in comparing oil painting and lithograph.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: This is in marked contrast to the painting by Fantin-Latour despite the difficulty in comparing oil paintings and lithography.
This is in marked contrast to the painting by Fantin-Latour despite the difficulty in comparing oil paintings and lithography.

sen.j: 左の絵では比較しにくいが、ジャポニズム以前の絵画では、地平線の位置が画面中央付近から下部に水平に表現されるのが普通であった。
sen.e: In the paintings before the introduction of Japonism, the horizon was usually depicted horizontally in the lower half of the picture, although it is difficult to understand this tendency by comparing two pictures shown in the left.

In paintings before the introduction of Japonism, the horizon was usually depicted horizontally in the lower half of the picture, although it is difficult to compare this in the two pictures shown on the left.

In paintings before the introduction of Japonism, the horizon was usually depicted horizontally in the lower half of the picture, although it is difficult to compare this in the two pictures shown on the left.

sen.j: ジャポニズム以降は地平線が画面上部に描かれたり、あるいは背景全部が地面または床になることが普通に見られるようになる。
sen.e: After the introduction of Japonism, such technique that the horizon was depicted in the upper half of the picture or only ground or floor occupied the whole background of the picture became common.

After the introduction of Japonism, techniques in which the horizon was depicted in the upper half of the picture or the entire background of the picture was occupied by ground or floor became commonplace.

After the introduction of Japonism, techniques in which the horizon was depicted in the upper half of the picture or the entire background of the picture was occupied by ground or floor became commonplace.

sen.j: このようなジャポニズムの影響は、20世紀に入るとヨーロッパのあらゆる視覚表現に普遍的に見られるようになる。
sen.e: These influence of Japonism were generally observed in every visual representation of Europe in the 20th century.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: These influences of Japonism came to be commonly seen in all visual representation within Europe during the 20th century.
These influences of Japonism came to be commonly seen in all visual representation within Europe during the 20th century.

sen.j: これはジャポニズムでこちらはそうではない、と区別することが意味を成さなくなっていく。
sen.e: As a result, it became nonsense to draw a clear line between works with the influence of Japonism and works without the influence of Japonism.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: As a result, it became futile to attempt to make a clear distinction between works influenced by Japonism and those that are not.
As a result, it became futile to attempt to make a clear distinction between works influenced by Japonism and those that are not.
